Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer committed a reviewable error in applying s. 49(1.1) of the Immigration Act
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 49(1.1)
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence that the sons did not sojourn in the U.S.
Decision_Outcome: Motion granted for Maria Eva Rivera Aguilar; dismissed for her sons
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to demonstrate they did not sojourn in the U.S.
Legal_Rule: Automatic stay of removal under s. 49(1.1) does not apply if claimant resided or sojourned in the U.S.
Grounds_for_Claim: Refugee claimants denied status and facing removal
Outcome_on_Merits: Mother qualifies for automatic stay; sons do not due to lack of evidence
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Partial success: stay granted for mother, denied for sons
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and nature of U.S. transit: one day for mother, two weeks for sons
Applicant_Challenge: Removal order following refugee claim denial
Court_Result: Automatic stay applies only to mother
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 49(1.1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Type: Travel history, duration of stay in U.S.
Outcome: Removal allowed for sons; stayed for mother
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and stay of removal
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 49(1.1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Rule: s. 49(1.1), IRPA â€“ Automatic stay exception for U.S. sojourners
